MEMC uses a formal Chemical Registration process that will not allow any new chemical substance in the plant unless it has received proper review for safe use, storage, and eventual disposal.  Chemical usage is tracked by month, by chemical, and by department.


40 CFR 68.155(d)
Five-Year Accident History

Within five years of the date of this revision, there have been no releases of any regulated substance above the threshold quantity from a covered process.

Therefore, there is no information available about deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damages, evacuations, or sheltering in place, because none of these occurred in the five-year period.

Also, none have occurred during the 64 years the facility has been in operation.


40 CFR 68.155(e)
Emergency Response Program 

All employees are trained to dial the Plant Emergency Hotline from any plant telephone in case of a chemical release, fire, or medical emergency of any kind.  That emergency number is also posted on all plant telephones.  The Hotline and the plant's emergency alarms go to the security desk in the main lobby.  The security officers activate the site Emergency Response Team paging system and will summon other plant resources, including Central County Fire and Rescue when needed.

The response is handled by the plant's Emergency Response Team, and Central County Fire and Rescue when necessary.  MEMC ERT members are 40-hour HazWoper trained and given refresher training annually.  Emergency Medical First Aid training has also been provided. Periodically, MEMCs ERT and Central County Fire and Rescue review emergency responses and plans and conduct joint training exercises.
 

In the event of an emergency with off-site consequences, MEMC would work with Central County Fire and Rescue. 40 CFR 68.155(c)
General Accident Release Prevention and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

MEMC accidental release prevention for hydrogen chloride is based on the Process Safety Management standard.  Elements of the PSM program include evergreen and actively maintained written operating procedures that are followed by trained and knowledgeable technicians.
 
Over time, MEMC has built a collection of detailed process safety procedures to insure standardized chemical handling and usage. The procedures begin with a safety section to reinforce the main theme of Safety First.  Management Of Change is formally controlled in covered processes to ensure that no unauthorized changes occur.  Job Safety Analyses or Risk Assessments are also used as applicable, to identify hazards, and control risks.  These are step-by-step reviews of tasks to ensure these jobs are done according to the safety standard.

Prevention steps include:
?	Tank and vessel inspection program to check mechanical integrity
?	Safety relief valve test program to ensure equipment functions as designed
?	Process Line Entry Permit for servicing piping and equipment and returning it to service
?	Hot Work Permits, Fire Prevention Plans, and related procedures
?	Sprinkler systems and firewalls to minimize the threat of fire or explosion
?	Access to the hydrogen chloride tank storage area is restricted to trained and authorized employees

MEMC measures the Serious Incident Rate for the plant each month, to include all accidents and incidents and potential incidents, not simply injuries.  Those classified as Serious Incidents are formally investigated and tracked in a Corrective Action Request system.
